question: Your project team members have just started to address the project work, technical decisions, and the project management approach. However, the team members are not collaborative or open to differing ideas and perspectives. Which stage of the Tuckman ladder has your team just entered?
explanation: answer D. Storming. During this phase, the team begins to address the project work, technical decisions, and the project management approach. If team members are not collaborative or open to differing ideas and perspectives, the environment can become counterproductive

question: A project manager is managing a research project. Typically, research projects are not clearly defined and involve a lot of uncertainty. While reviewing project progress, the project manager assesses that an activity has been missed from the activity list. A milestone, scheduled to be achieved within another month, would be missed with the current implementation Activity Plan.  Which of the following options should be the first action for the project manager to take?
a: Assess alternatives to meet the milestone
b: Report the error and the expected delay
c: Omit the status update on the milestone
d: Report the error and the planned recovery actions
explanation: answer A. Indicates confronting the issue with an attempt to resolve the issue. Hence this would be the first action to take followed by reporting the issue correctly. Options B and D, that is, ‘report the error and the expected delay’ or ‘report the error and the planned recovery actions’ do not make any attempt to solve the problem.

question: Your project has a 20% probability of profiting $15,000. There is a 15% probability of a loss of $30,000. What is the expected monetary value of this situation?
explanation: answer: C. Expected monetary value is calculated be EMV=Probability*Impact We need to calculate both positive and nagative values and then add to them. (EMV) to profit = +$15,000*20%=+$ 3,000 (EMV) to loss = -$30,000*15%= - $4,500 EMV= EMV to profit + EMV to loss EMV=$3,000+ $(-4,500) = - $1,500 = 1,500 loss

question: You are a project manager in a construction project, and your project has been completed and is in the process of closing. Which of the following techniques should you consider in this process?
explanation: Tools and techniques of the close project or phase are (Very important): .1 Expert judgment .2 Data analysis • Document analysis • Regression analysis • Trend analysis • Variance analysis 3 Meetings. . [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 121]

question: A project manager you are mentoring comes to you for help because he is about to face his first procurement audit. You may explain that he should not be worried about such an audit, because an audit is primarily concerned with:
a: Makes sure that the contract is being followed
b: Makes sure the schedule of the project in line with the schedule baseline
c: Makes sure the deliverables are accepted
d: Review of contracting processes for completeness, accuracy, and effectiveness
explanation: answer D. For the exam, the primary purpose of the procurement audit is to identify lessons learned during the procurement process. Procurement audits examine the procurement process to determine areas of improvement (successes) and to identify flawed (failures) processes or procedures. This allows you to reuse the successful processes on other procurement items for this project, on future projects, or elsewhere in the organization. It also alerts you to problems in the process so that you don't repeat them. . [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 714]

question: In which phase is the project kickoff meeting established?
explanation: answer B. The project kickoff meeting is established in the planning phase and before beginning of the implementation phase. [PMI PMP Examination Content Outline – June 2015- PERFORMANCE DOMAIN II: PLANNING-Task # 12]

question: As a project manager in a construction project, the project sponsor has told you that the project will be terminated due to stumbling in regards to the credit limit of the bank. What could have been done to prevent this kind of situation?
explanation: answer C. Funding limit reconciliation involves reconciling the amount of funds to be spent with the amount of funds budgeted for the project. The organization or the customer sets these limits. Reconciling the project expenses will require adjusting the schedule so that the expenses can be smoothed. You do this by placing imposed date constraints on work packages or other WBS components in the project schedule. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 253]

question: You are a project manager for a construction project. Only 85% of the total work was completed, and the project took up the whole budget because of a change in the cost of materials. The cost of the material during the estimation of the project budget is US $7.00, and your estimate is US $10.00. During the implementation phase, if the cost of the material reached US $16.00, what should have been your estimate of the material during the project budget estimate?
explanation: answer C. There is a risk occurred because the project has spent its budget and only 85% completed. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 245] Where, O=US $7.00, M=US $10.00, P= US $16.00 E (Be,t(A) = (16+4*10+7)/6 = $10.5 (Option C)

question: In which process are the project deliverables reviewed and accepted?
explanation: answer A. Validate scope is where the customer and sponsor verify that the deliverables match what was in the scope. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 131]

question: You are showing your project team members the organizational structure, and you point out where in the structure their role is located. What tool would be useful to you in preparing this information?
explanation: answer C. The organizational breakdown structure (OBS) is arranged according to an organizations existing departments, units, or teams with the project activities or work packages listed under each department. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 316]

question: After brainstorming potential project risks, what is the recommended method for prioritizing these risks and their mitigation plans?
explanation: probability and impact matrix prioritizes the combination of probability and impact scores and helps you determine which risks need detailed risk response plans. For example, a risk event with a high probability of occurring and a high impact will likely need a response plan. This matrix is typically defined by the organization, but if you don’t have one, you’ll need to develop this now—during your planning meetings (a tool and technique of this process). You’ll use this matrix in the Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis process, and I’ll talk more in depth about it in the section “Analyzing Risks Using Qualitative Techniques” later in this chapter. Again, you want to define (or modify) and document the probability and impact matrix in the risk management plan. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 472]

question: You are about to contract out a project to a service provider. However, at the time of awarding the contract, you are not sure of the total effort involved. Since the scope of work cannot be accurately estimated, you want to agree upon the per unit rates for different services. Which of the following contracts would best suit your purpose?
explanation: answer B. Time and materials (T&M) contracts are a cross between fixed-price and cost-reimbursable contracts. The full amount of the material costs is not known at the time the contract is awarded. This resembles a cost-reimbursable contract because the costs will continue to grow during the contract’s life and are reimbursable to the contractor. The buyer bears the biggest risk in this type of contract. • T&M contracts can resemble fixed-price contracts when unit rates are used, for example. Unit rates might be used to preset the rates of certain elements or portions of the project. For example, a contracting agency might charge you $150 per hour for a .NET programmer, or a leasing company might charge you $2,000 per month for the hardware you’re leasing during the testing phase of your project. These rates are preset and agreed upon by the buyer and seller ahead of time. • T&M contracts are most often used when you need human resources with specific skills and when you can quickly and precisely define the scope of work needed for the project. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 472]

question: As a project manager, you are participating in the process of developing a project charter. Which of the following documents will help you in this process?
explanation: answer B. The benefits management plan is part of the business documents. The business case and the benefits management plan are sources of information about the project´s objectives and how the project will contribute to the business goals. Although the business documents are developed prior to the project, they are reviewed periodically. Inputs of the project charter must be memorized prior taking the PMP Exam.

question: You are a project manager participating in the process of developing a project charter. You have received a letter stating that the customer is interested in the KPIs. As a project manager, what should you do next?
a: You should include KPIs in the project charter
b: Include KPIs in the project management plan
c: Don’t include KPIs In the project charter
d: Include KPIs in change management plan
explanation: answer A. Refer to PMBOK 5, chapter 4 integration management knowledge area, key performance indicators can be part of project management information systems (PMIS), and (PMIS) is part of enterprise environmental Factors (E.E.F) which is input in develop a project charter (PMBOK 5th Edition -70), and the project charter intended to satisfy measurable project objectives and related success criteria (Key performance indicators) [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 95]

question: You are the project manager for the design of a software development project. In order to determine ideal settings for the software quality, the quality manager of the company suggests trying out various scenarios in order to influence specific variables of a product or process under development or in production while keeping manufacturing costs and Software efficiency of the final product within specific limits. Identifying such Variables which influence the product or process under development is called:
explanation: answer B. • DOE is a statistical technique that identifies the elements—or variables—that will have the greatest effect on overall project outcomes. It is used most often concerning the product of the project but can also be applied to project management processes to examine trade-offs. • DOE designs and sets up experiments to determine the ideal solution for a problem using a limited number of sample cases. It analyzes several variables at once, allowing you to change all (or some of) the variables at the same time and determine which combination will produce the best result at a reasonable cost. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 290]

question: You are comparing your project to another external project, which is similar to your project as a basis for measuring performance. This activity can best be described as:
explanation: answer B. Benchmarking involves comparing actual or planned project practices to those of comparable projects to identify best practices, generate ideas for improvement, and provide a basis for measuring performance. Benchmarked projects may exist within the performing organization or outside of it, or can be within the same application area. Benchmarking allows for analogies from projects in a different application area to be made. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Fifth Edition, Page 134]

question: Which of the following is considered an output from the Close Project or Phase Process?
explanation: answer A. Outputs from the close project or phase process are (Very important for the exam): PROJECT DOCUMENTS UPDATES, FINAL PRODUCT, SERVICE, OR RESULT TRANSITION, FINAL REPORT and ORGANIZATIONAL PROCESS ASSET UPDATES. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 128]

question: You are a project manager, and your organization is preparing for the internal quality audit cycle. However, you feel that the project team is a little apprehensive about the audit process. Who is responsible for conducting the project quality audit?
explanation: nswer D. Quality audits may be scheduled or random, and may be conducted by internal or external auditors. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 295]

question: Correct Which conflict resolution technique is best for a long-lasting solution?
explanation: answer C. The collaborate technique is also called problem solve and is the best way to resolve conflict. One of the key actions you'll perform with this technique is a fact-finding mission. The thinking here is that one right solution to a problem exists and the facts will bear out the solution. Once the facts are uncovered, they're presented to the parties and the decision will be clear. Thus, the solution becomes a permanent one and the conflict expires. This is a win-win solution. Multiple viewpoints are discussed and shared using this technique, and team members have the opportunity to examine all the perspectives of the issue. Collaborating will lead to true consensus where team members commit to the decision. This is the conflict resolution approach project managers use most often and is an example of a win-win conflict resolution technique [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 349]

question: You have been assigned as the project manager of an existing project involving 40 company employees and seven sub-contractors, and you would like to know the project resources assigned to each work package in your project. Where should you look for this information?
explanation: answer A. Responsibility Assignment Matrix (RAM). A grid that shows the project resources assigned to each work package. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 720]

question: As a project manager, if you decided to purchase insurance coverage for your project risks, purchasing insurance is an example of which risk response strategy?
explanation: nswer A. Risk transference nearly always involves payment of a risk premium to the party taking on the risk. Transferring liability for risk is most effective in dealing with financial risk exposure. Transference tools can be quite diverse and include, but are not limited to, the use of insurance, performance bonds, warranties, guarantees, etc. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 443]

question: Measuring the square footage of a building and then multiplying that figure by a set cost factor for construction is an example of:
explanation: answer A. Parametric estimating is a quantitatively based estimating method that multiplies the quantity of work by the rate or uses an algorithm in conjunction with historical data to determine cost, budget, or duration estimates. The best way to describe it is with an example. Suppose you are working on a companywide network upgrade project. This requires you to run new cable to the switches on every floor in the building. To come up with an estimate, you can use parametric estimates to determine activity duration estimates by taking a known element—in this case, the amount of cable needed—and multiplying it by the amount of time it takes to install a unit of cable. In other words, suppose you have 10,000 meters of new cable to run. You know from past experience it takes 1 hour to install 100 meters. Using this measurement, you can determine an estimate for this activity of 100 hours to run the new cable. Therefore, the cable activity duration estimate is 100 hours. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Pages 200 & 201]

question: Comparing actual or planned project practices to those of other projects to generate ideas for improvement is known as
explanation: answer A. Benchmarking. Benchmarking involves comparing actual or planned project practices or the project’s quality standards to those of comparable projects to identify best practices, generate ideas for improvement, and provide a basis for measuring performance. Benchmarked projects may exist within the performing organization or outside of it, or can be within the same application area or other application area. Benchmarking allows for analogies from projects in a different application area or different industries to be made. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Pages 281]

question: You are reviewing an earned value report and observed that the CPI was 0.98, and the SPI is 1.05. You will report to the project sponsor that the project is:
a: Right on plan according to schedule and budget baselines
b: Ahead of schedule and over budget
d: Not enough information to determine the project condition
explanation: answer B. A CPI less than one indicates that the project is performing over budget. An SPI that greater than one indicates that the project is performing ahead of schedule. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Pages 263]

question: Which of the following is a tool or technique used in the manage stakeholder engagements process?
explanation: answer D. Interpersonal skills is an important technique used in the manage stakeholder engagements process. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Fifth Edition, Page 407]

question: You are a project manager and your project is currently in the implementation phase. You would like to know more about the project deliverables, work required to complete those deliverables, project constraints, and assumptions. Which of the following documents would be most useful for this purpose?
explanation: answer D. The preparation of a detailed project scope statement builds upon the major deliverables, assumptions, and constraints that are documented during project initiation. During project planning, the project scope is defined and described with greater specificity as more information about the project is known. Existing risks, assumptions, and constraints are analyzed for completeness and added or updated as necessary. The Define Scope process can be highly iterative. In iterative life cycle projects, a high-level vision will be developed for the overall project, but the detailed scope is determined one iteration at a time, and the detailed planning for the next iteration is carried out as work progresses on the current project scope and deliverables. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 151]

question: You have been managing a construction project in a developing country. However, you determine that the project requires a construction management expert who is not available from the company in your country. Upon doing some research, you determine that the company has a construction management expert based in Chicago, and he is qualified for the project. However, the Chicago-based employee is not willing to relocate to your country for the project. In such a case:
a: Negotiate with the functional manager of the Chicago based employee and inform him that the employee needs to be convinced to relocate to your project.
b: You would look at the option of moving ahead with the project by using the construction manager as a virtual team.
c: Manage the project without the key resource and consider this as a risk.
d: Request your project sponsor to get more resources.
explanation: answer B. Virtual teams/distributed teams. The globalization of projects has promoted the need for virtual teams that work on the same project, but are not colocated at the same site. The availability of communication technology such as email, audio conferencing, social media, web-based meetings, and video conferencing has made virtual teams feasible. Managing virtual teams has unique advantages, such as being able to use special expertise on a project team even when the expert is not in the same geographic area, incorporating employees who work from home offices, and including people with mobility limitations or disabilities. The challenges of managing virtual teams are mainly in the communication domain, including a possible feeling of isolation, gaps in sharing knowledge and experience between team members, and difficulties in tracking progress and productivity, possible time zone difference and cultural differences. The other choices are not valid.[(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 311]

question: You are participating in developing the project charter for a new project assigned to you. Which of the following is an element/s of the enterprise environmental factors?
d: Risk templates and financial control procedures
explanation: answer B. The enterprise environmental factors that can influence the Develop Project Charter process include but are not limited to: • Structure, culture and infrastructure (e.g., product standards, quality standards, safety standards, and workmanship standards). • Legal and regulatory requirements and/or constraints. • Marketplace conditions. • Organizational culture and political climate. • Organizational governance framework (a structured way to provide control, direction, and coordination through people, policies, and processes to meet organizational strategic and operational goals), and Stakeholders’ expectations and risk thresholds. .[(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 78]

question: The Project Stakeholder Management knowledge area is focused on engaging the stakeholders in the project. As you’ve been managing your project, you found out that one of the key stakeholders of the company is resisting the project. As a project manager, what must you do first?
a: Analyze options that might change or influence the key stakeholder perception.
b: Conduct a team meeting to discuss this issue.
c: Seek support from the project sponsor to force project decisions.
d: Seek expert judgment from the project initiator.
explanation: answer A. The key stakeholders must be turned into a project supporter in order to ensure success. Any of the given choices can be the solution to this problem. However, you should first identify all the available options and analyze them before selecting the best option. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Pages 521&522]

question: Your project has a budget of $2,000. After two-thirds of the project work is completed, the project has cost $1,500. Your project can be described as:
explanation: answer B. The project has a budget $2,000, So BAC=$2,000 EV =2/3*$2,000=$1,333 , AC=$1,500, CV=EV-AC = 1,333-1,500=-0.167 (over budget)

question: Which of the following is an input to the Close Project or Phase Process?
explanation: nswer A. Lessons learned register. Described in Section 4.3.3.1. The lessons learned in the phase or project will be finalized before being entered into the lessons learned repository. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 124]

question: As a project manager, you understand the importance of project files, records, and correspondence for future references. Which of the following can be used to manage records and correspondence?
explanation: answer D. Historical Information. Documents and data on prior projects including project files, records, correspondence, closed contracts, and closed projects. [(PMBOK) Sixth Edition, Page 708  – Glossary]

question: As part of a joint venture, a project manager working with another company needs to share some confidential information related to intellectual property rights. He wants to know the person responsible for authorizing the release of this confidential information. Which project document would record the details of the person responsible for authorizing the release of this confidential information?
explanation: answer C. A project communication management plan would record the details of the person responsible for authorizing release of this confidential information on the project. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 377]

question: You are the project manager in your organization. The project is in the planning phase. You are meeting with your stakeholders to gather requirements for your project. You are well aware that requirements to be gathered include both product and project requirements. You are using a technique that one individual takes responsibility for making the decision for the group to collect the requirements. What is an appropriate technique to use?
explanation: answer C. Autocratic decision making involves one person making the decision on behalf of the group. Unanimity: everyone agrees on a single course of action. Majority: This occurs when the majority of stakeholders agree on the decision. Focus groups: bring together prequalified stakeholders and subject matter experts to learn about their expectations and attitudes about a proposed product, service, or result. A trained moderator guides the group through an interactive discussion designed to be more conversational than a one-on-one interview. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Pages 144 & 142]

question: Your project has an SPI of 1.01 and a CPI of 0.90. What does this mean?
a: The project is over budget and ahead of schedule.
b: The project is ahead of schedule but under budget.
c: The project is over budget and behind schedule.
d: The project is behind schedule and under budget.
explanation: answer A. A Schedule Performance Index (SPI) > 1 means that the project is ahead of schedule because the work is progressing at a rate of greater than what was planned. A Cost Performance Index (CPI) < 1 means that the project is over budget because we are getting less value for the money spent than what we had planned. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 267]

question: What is the main purpose of the project charter?
a: It contains the initial scope of work.
b: It contains the list of the project risks.
c: It authorizes the Project Manager to use organization resources to execute the project.
d: It identifies the project sponsor who will pay for the project.
explanation: answer C. The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. It documents the business needs, assumptions, constraints, the understanding of the customer’s needs and high-level requirements. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 81]

question: A Cost Performance Index (CPI) of 0.86 means?
a: The Project is only getting 86 cents out of every $1 spent.
b: The Project would cost 14% more than originally planned.
c: The Project is progressing at only 86% of the originally planned.
d: The Project would cost 86% more than originally planned.
explanation: answer A. The Project is only getting 86 cents out of every $1 spent. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 263]

question: The project manager develops a process improvement plan to encourage continuous process improvement during the life of the project. Which of the following is a valid tool or technique to assist the project manager in assuring the success of the process improvement plan?
explanation: answer B. Process analysis. Process analysis identifies opportunities for process improvements. This analysis also examines problems, constraints, and non-value-added activities that occur during a process. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 292]

question: You are participating in developing the project charter for a new project assigned to you. Which of the following is inputted in the Develop Project Charter?
c: Historical information and lessons learned repository
explanation: answer C. Historical information and lessons learned repository are part of organizational process assets. And the organizational process assets is input in the develop project charter. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 79]

question: While managing a project, you decide to create a prototype of your product first to ensure that it is acceptable to stakeholders before creating your product. Creating a prototype is an example of:
explanation: Risk A. Mitigation may require prototype development to reduce the risk of scaling up from a bench-scale model of a process or product. Where it is not possible to reduce probability, a mitigation response might address the risk impact by targeting linkages that determine the severity. For example, designing redundancy into a system may reduce the impact from a failure of the original component. [(PMBOK) – Sixth Edition, Page 443]

question: You are the project manager for a large construction project. The project objective is to construct a set of outbuildings to house the 2018 FIFA World Cup Russia™ team that will be arriving in Moscow City 8 months from the project start date. Resources are not readily available because they are currently assigned to other projects. John, an expert construction manager, is needed for this project two months from today. Which of the following skills will you use to get John assigned to your project?
explanation: answer A. Negotiation and influencing skills are needed to convince john's boss and come to an agreement concerning his assignment. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Pages 332& 333]

question: You are the project manager for a research project. You're performing cost estimates for your project and you don't have a lot of details yet. Which of the following techniques should you use?
explanation: answer is C. Analogous duration estimating is frequently used to estimate project duration when there is a limited amount of detailed information about the project. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 200]

question: Which of the following is a tool and technique used to identify stakeholders’ process?
explanation: answer is C. Stakeholder analysis. Stakeholder analysis results in a list of stakeholders and relevant information such as their positions in the organization, roles on the project, “stakes,” expectations, attitudes (their levels of support for the project), and their interest in information about the project. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 512]

question: The product scope description, deliverables, and acceptance criteria together describe elements of which of the following?
b: Tools and techniques of the Initiating processes
explanation: answer C. The project scope statement is the description of the project scope, major deliverables, assumptions, and constraints. The project scope statement documents the entire scope, including project and product scope. It describes the project’s deliverables in detail. It also provides a common understanding of the project scope among project stakeholders. It may contain explicit scope exclusions that can assist in managing stakeholder expectations. It enables the project team to perform more detailed planning, guides the project team’s work during execution, and provides the baseline for evaluating whether requests for changes or additional work are contained within or outside the project’s boundaries. [(PMBOK® ) – Sixth Edition, Page 154]

question: What are the inputs to the Develop Project Charter Process?
a: Business case – Project Management Plan – Agreements – Enterprise environmental factors - Organizational process assets.
b: Business case - Benefits management plan – Agreements – Enterprise environmental factors - Organizational process assets.
c: Business case – Project charter – Agreements – Enterprise environmental factors - Organizational process assets.
d: Business case – Outputs from other processes – Agreements – Enterprise environmental factors - Organizational process assets.
explanation: answer B. Inputs of the project charter are (Very important for the exam): 1 - Business documents • Business case • Benefits management plan 2-Agreements 3- Enterprise environmental factors 4- Organizational process assets [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 75]

question: Your organization is preparing to construct a new villa. You worked on a similar project for the organization two years ago. Which of the following might be most helpful to you on your new project?
b: Historical information from a previous similar project
d: The organization's project management information systems
explanation: answer B. Historical information on projects of a similar nature can be helpful when initiating new projects. They can help in formulating project deliverables and identifying constraints and assumptions and will be helpful later in the project planning processes as well.

question: You are in the process of identifying your stakeholders. You are using one of the tools and techniques of this process. Which of the following techniques should you use to identify the stakeholders?
explanation: answer A. Tools and techniques that are used in the identify stakeholders process are (Expert judgment - Data gathering - Data analysis - Data representation and Meetings). [(PMBOK® ) – Sixth Edition,  504]

question: You are a project manager responsible for the construction of a new office complex. You are taking over for a project manager who recently left the company. The prior project manager completed the define scope process. What is the next process that you should start?
b: Subdividing project deliverables and project work into smaller, more manageable components
explanation: answer B Create WBS is the process of subdividing project deliverables and project work into smaller, more manageable components. The key benefit of this process is that it provides a framework of what has to be delivered. This process is performed once or at predefined points in the project.

question: You are a project manager for a construction project.A strike by local workers occurs due to the lateness of workers' payments. That leads to delays in a major component delivery in your project. What could have been done differently to prevent this type of situation?
explanation: What-If Scenario Analysis is the correct answer. What-if scenario analysis is the process of evaluating scenarios in order to predict their effect, positively or negatively, on project objectives. This is an analysis of the question“What if the situation represented by scenario ‘A strike’ happened?” The outcome of the what-if scenario analysis can be used to assess the feasibility of the project schedule under adverse conditions, and in preparing contingency and response plans to overcome or mitigate the impact of the unexpected situation. Option (A) Crashing Is a schedule compression technique involves adding additional resources. In order to compress the project schedule. Crashing always results in increased costs. Option (C) Leads and lags are both used in the development of the project schedule. Lead is an acceleration of the successor activity and can be used only on finish-to-start activity relationships. Lag is a delay in the successor activity and can be found on all activity relationship types. Option (D) fast-tracking is schedule compression technique involves taking critical path activities that were originally planned in series and doing them parallel. Fast-tracking often results in rework and usually increase the project risk. Tracking: is schedule compression technique involves taking critical path activities that were originally planned in series and doing them parallel. Fast-tracking often results in rework and usually increase the project risk.

question: You are a project manager who is in charge of an important project for your company, and your project is currently in the implementation phase. If the project sponsor has told the functional manager that the project will be delayed by two weeks, and the functional manager has told you to document that, which organizational structure do you work in?
explanation: In Functional organization, the Project manager has the least authority in a functional organization structure. Option (B) Projectized: in Projectized organization the project manager has full authority to assign priorities, apply resources, and direct the work of persons assigned to the project. Option (D) Tight Matrix: in Tight Matrix Organization it simply refers to (colocation), or locating the workspace for the project team in the same room. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 47]

question: You are a project manager for a software project. You have been assigned as a project manager instead of a previous project manager. The previous project manager was fired because he failed to send project information to the stakeholders involved in the project. What could have done differently by the previous project manager to prevent this type of situation?
explanation: answer: B. The previous project manager failed to send information to the project's stakeholders. He should have reviewed the communication management plans; it contains the following: • who needs what information, and who is authorized to access that information; • When they will need the information; • Where the information should be stored; • what format the information should be stored in; • How the information can be retrieved. According to the PMI® Project Management Professional (PMP) ® Examination Content Outline, the communications management plan defines and manages the flow of project information For the exam, know that the communications management plan documents how the communication needs of the stakeholders will be met, including the types of information that will be communicated, who will communicate it, who receives the communication, the methods used to communicate, the timing and frequency, the method for updating this plan as the project progresses, the escalation process, and a glossary of common terms. question: Your equipment supplier left you a voicemail saying that the Hurricane season in the Eastern North Pacific will prevent your equipment from arriving on time. You identified a risk response strategy for this risk and had arranged for a local company to lease you the needed equipment until yours arrives. This is an example of which risk response strategy?
explanation: answer: C. Mitigation attempts to reduce the impact of a risk event should it occurs. Making plans to arrange for the leased equipment reduces the consequences of the risk. When you mitigate a risk, you attempt to reduce the probability of a risk event occurring or reduce its impacts to an acceptable level. This strategy is a lot like defensive driving. You see an obstacle in the road ahead, survey your options, and take the necessary steps to avoid the obstacle and proceed safely on your journey. Seeing the obstacle ahead (identifying risk) allows you to reduce the threat by planning ways around it or planning ways to reduce its impact if the risk does occur (mitigation strategies). According to the PMBOK® Guide, the purpose of mitigation is to reduce the probability that a risk will occur and/or reduce the impact of the risk to a level where you can accept the risk and its outcomes. It's easier to take actions early on that will reduce the probability of a risk event or its consequences than it is to fix the damage once it has occurred. Some examples of risk mitigation include performing more tests, using less complicated processes, creating prototypes, and choosing more reliable vendors. For The Exam, 1. Strategies for Negative Risks or Threats  Avoid: It usually involves changing the project management plan to eliminate the threat entirely.  Examples: extending the schedule, changing the Strategy, or reducing scope.  Transfer: is a risk response strategy whereby the project team shifts the impact of a threat to a third party, transferring the risk simply gives another party responsibility for its management—it does not eliminate it .  Examples: Buy insurance, performance bonds, warranties guarantees, a fixed-price contract may transfer risk to the seller. Use of a cost-plus contract may transfer the cost risk to the buyer.  Mitigate: is a risk response strategy whereby the project team acts to reduce the probability of occurrence or impact of a risk.  Examples: prototypes, designing redundancy into a system may reduce the impact from a failure of the original component.  Accept: This strategy indicates that the project team has decided not to change the project management plan to deal with a risk, or is unable to identify any other suitable response strategy.(strategy for both threats and Opportunities)  Examples: active acceptance strategy is to establish a contingency reserve, including amounts of time, money, or resources to handle the risks. 2. Strategies for Positive Risks or Opportunities  Exploit: The exploit strategy may be selected for risks with positive impacts where the organization wishes to ensure that the opportunity is realized.  Examples: assigning an organization’s most talented resources to the project to reduce the time to completion or using new technologies or technology upgrades to reduce cost and duration required to realize project objectives.  Enhance: The enhance strategy is used to increase the probability and/or the positive impacts of an opportunity. question: You are the project manager for a factory construction project. You are annoyed with one of the subcontractors who is working on your project because of his constant disagreements. You asked him to stop arguing and do the work the way in which you want it to be done. The conflict handling approach you are following is:
explanation: answer B. The following are six methods of conflict management: Direct/Forcing: One person forces a solution on the other parties. This is an example of a win-lose conflict resolution technique. • Smoothing/Accommodating: Smoothing/accommodating is a temporary way to resolve conflict where the areas of agreement are emphasized over the areas of difference so the real issue stays buried. This is an example of a lose-lose conflict resolution technique because neither side wins. • Compromise: Compromise is achieved when each of the parties involved in the conflict gives up something to reach a solution. This is an example of a no-win conflict resolution technique, because neither side gets what they wanted. • Confrontation/Problem Solving: Confrontation and problem solving are the best ways to resolve conflict. One of the key actions performed with this technique is a fact-finding mission. This is the conflict resolution approach project managers use most often and is an example of a win-win conflict resolution technique. • Collaborating: when multiple viewpoints are discussed and shared and team members have the opportunity to examine all the perspectives of the issue, collaboration occurs. Collaborating will lead to true consensus where team members commit to the decision. • Withdrawal/Avoidance: One of the parties gets up, leaves, and refuses to discuss the conflict. This is an example of a lose-lose conflict resolution technique. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 349]

question: You are a project manager for a construction project, and electrical power in your project frequently experiences outages. This affects the Internet Servers. As part of a strategy to handle this negative risk, you decided to rent a generator to run in case of power failure. This is an example of which risk response strategy?
explanation: answer: C. Mitigation attempts to reduce the impact of a risk event should it occurs. Making plans to arrange for the rented generator reduces the consequences of the risk. When you mitigate a risk, you attempt to reduce the probability of a risk event occurring or reduce its impacts to an acceptable level. This strategy is a lot like defensive driving. You see an obstacle along the road ahead, survey your options, and take the necessary steps to avoid the obstacle and proceed safely on your journey. Seeing the obstacle ahead (identifying risk) allows you to reduce the threat by planning ways around it or planning ways to reduce its impact if the risk does occur (mitigation strategies). According to the PMBOK® Guide, the purpose of mitigation is to reduce the probability that a risk will occur and/or reduce the impact of the risk to a level where you can accept the risk and its outcomes. It's easier to take actions early on that will reduce the probability of a risk event or its consequences than it is to fix the damage once it has occurred. Some examples of risk mitigation include performing more tests, using less complicated processes, creating prototypes, and choosing more reliable vendors. [PMBOK Sixth edition, Page 443]

question: You are the project manager of a pharmaceutical company responsible for releasing a new drug on the market. question: You are managing a large construction project. The project is currently in the executing phase. While you are assessing your project risks, you found that one of the acceptable risks will occur. Which of the following techniques will you use as part of your Implement Risk Response?

question: After several months of negotiations, your organization is almost ready to sign a contract. question: You are a project manager for a large construction project. You are in a meeting with the key stakeholders to know about their expectations and attitudes about a proposed product; which of the following tools and techniques are you using?

question: In your project, if an optimistic estimate for an activity = 5 days, Most likely = 8 days and pessimistic estimate (P) = 10 days, using Triangular distribution, what is the estimate activity duration for this activity?

question: You are working on a software development project using an agile approach. You want to improve the way that the team builds software, so you get them all to improve collaboratively and evolve experimentally by coming up with changes that they can make to their process together, and by using data to figure out if those changes made things better. Your project teams are focused on flowing work through the system to completion and not beginning new work until work in progress is completed. Which of the following methods are you using?
explanation: answer B. The Kanban Method (Is very important for the exam) may be best used when a team or organization is in need of the following conditions: • Flexibility. Productivity and quality are increased by limiting work in progress. • Increased efficiency. Checking each task for value adding or non-value-added activities and removing the non-value adding activities. • Team member focus. Limited work in progress allows the team to focus on the current work. • Variability in the workload. Transparency makes waste visible so it can be removed. [PMBOK Sixth edition, Pages 103-108 Annex A3]

question: You are a project manager. The sponsor has requested you to provide duration estimates for your project, and you come across a similar project completed by your organization last year. To save time, you use information from this project to help estimate activity duration. This is an example of which tool or technique?
explanation: answer D. Analogous estimating is a technique for estimating the duration or cost of an activity or a project using historical data from a similar activity or project. Analogous estimating uses parameters from a previous, similar project, such as duration, budget, size, weight, and complexity, as the basis for estimating the same parameter or measure for a future project.  When estimating durations, this technique relies on the actual duration of previous, similar projects as the basis for estimating the duration of the current project. It is a gross value estimating approach, sometimes adjusted for known differences in project complexity. Analogous duration estimating is frequently used to estimate project duration when there is a limited amount of detailed information about the project.  Analogous estimating is generally less costly and less time-consuming than other techniques, but it is also less accurate. [(PMBOK® Guide) – Sixth Edition, Page 200]
